docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY -- The Legislature approved an emergency budget bill on Monday that would authorize Gov. David A. Paterson to furlough about 100,000 state employees, roughly half the state's work force, without pay for one day. Public employee unions contended that the furloughs, which officials said would be the first for state workers in New York, would be illegal, and they said they would seek a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court here to block Mr. Paterson's plan.

headline.main: Paterson Pushes Through a Bill To Furlough Workers for a Day

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature approves emergency budget bill that will authorize Gov David A Paterson to furlough about 100,000 state employees, roughly half of state's work force, without pay for one day; public employee unions contend that furloughs, which officials say will be first for state workers in New York, are illegal; say they will seek temporary restraining order to block Paterson's plan; while some lawmakers, including many who voted for bill, also question legality of furloughs, they say they had little choice but to approve legislation because failing to do so would have effectively shut down state government; furlough plan, which will require each affected worker to take one day off next week, is part of emergency spending bill needed to keep money flowing to state agencies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA - President Obama is about to be thrust firmly behind Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the Republican-turned Democrat who is facing a very tough challenge for the Democratic nomination here in a primary next Tuesday. Mr. Specter announced tonight that he will begin airing an advertisement tomorrow that features a testimonial from the president.
docs.abstract: Senator Arlen Specter, the Republican-turned-Democrat seeking his sixth term, faces a tough challenge from Representative Joe Sestak in next week's Democratic primary.
docs.snippet: Senator Arlen Specter, the Republican-turned-Democrat seeking his sixth term, faces a tough challenge from Representative Joe Sestak in next week's Democratic primary.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, National Review's editors quoted my praise for Utah's soon-to-be ex-senator, Bob Bennett, in the course of arguing that conservatives shouldn't feel any regret over his Tea Party-abetted defeat. Since the case against Bennett emphasized his support for the bipartisan Wyden-Bennett health care bill, NR's editorial focuses on that legislation's drawbacks:
docs.abstract: Why conservatives should regret the Utah Senator's defeat.
docs.snippet: Why conservatives should regret the Utah Senator's defeat.
